Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Clinical Workforce Schedule Optimization Technology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will be that a novel clinical schedule optimization technology developed based on a prior NSF funded research project can be used to reduce staffing costs in health systems. The technology will also help improve patient safety. Results from prior analysis suggest that significant joint operational and safety costs savings are possible using the system. Since staffing costs, specifically clinical workforce costs, constitute a significant portion of healthcare costs, a large impact on overall health care costs can result from successful implementation of the schedule optimization technology. Additional safety benefits will offer potential further savings.

This I-Corps project with help explore the processes used in making staffing and scheduling decisions for the clinical staff, and how the developed clinical schedule optimization technology can potentially be leveraged to improve these decisions in real operational settings. The findings from this exploration will help the investigator team to understand the market readiness for this technology, and the viability of potential products and services to help improve hospital systems. This will inform the technology's further development by determining the target market and understanding of current staffing products and solutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this grant was to evaluate technology-market fit for the methodology developed from the previously funded basic science research. Following specific objectives were identified:

Objective 1:  Interview a wide range of stakeholders to evaluate the need and practicality of the developed technology.

Objective 2: Perform a cost-benefit analysis of the developed technology.

Outcome:

The team participated in the NSF iCorps program during the Fall 2018 program at Houston. It successfully completed this program, which required completion of at least 100 stakeholder interviews in this area. The team continued with the interviewing process after the completion of the program. Stakeholders from a multitude of different organizations across geographical regions and level of responsibilities within hospital systems were engaged in the interviewing process. Additionally, solutions provided by the current vendors were explored. The interviews were conducted using face-to-face, online and phone. Clinical conferences were attended, and stakeholder were interviewed and technology usability assessments were made through these conferences. Furthermore, value proposition analysis were performed to evaluate the cost and benefits of the developed solutions.

The team also found that the purchase decision making in a hospital is a highly complex process, involving multiple stakeholders. Each stakeholder has a different perspective, and needs. The sale-cycle itself is very long, extending from 12 to 24 months.

The interview process indicated the need for the proposed technology. It was found that the current solutions for the staffing problem inadequately address the issue of uncertainty in patient volume, particularly in the context of Emergency Departments.  The Entrepreneurs on the team decided to start a company (Medecipher, Inc) for further development of technology-based software solution. The company has been incorporated.

Key Outcomes:

  • Medecipher, Inc. has raised $100,000 through friends and family investments.
  • Medecipher, Inc. was one of the six finalist at the national competition Prime-Health that will be held in Denver on October 11, 2018.
  • Medecipher, Inc. was selected as one of the startup companies for the BoomTown accelerator program (less than 2% success rate). The program started in August, 2018.
  • Medecipher, Inc. was also selected as one of the startup companies for competing at the next level in the IGNITE competition to be held on 10/25/208 in Texas.

 


Last Modified: 02/01/2019
Modified by: Sanjay Mehrotra
